Today, the Consumer Protection & Commerce Subcommittee held a markup on 6 bills to:

- Stop furniture tip-overs
- Ban inclined sleepers 
- Ban crib bumpers
- Protect against carbon monoxide poisoning
- Make safer portable fuel containers
- Update furniture flammability standards pic.twitter.com/ttsfN7qIk7
Update: HR 2647 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

The last bill is HR 2647, the Safer Occupancy Furniture Flammability Act. This bipartisan bill was introduced by @DorisMatsui and @RepMGriffith and would adopt the California upholstered furniture flammability standard. pic.twitter.com/DEqfgqjRcs
Update: HR 806 was favorably reported to the full Committee, as amended, by a voice vote.

It will also direct @USCPSC to conduct an education campaign to alert consumers to the dangers of using or storing portable fuel containers near ignition sources and to report to Congress on the campaign.

HR 806, the Portable Fuel Container Safety Act of 2019, was introduced by @RepThompson and @RepDaveJoyce. This bipartisan legislation would direct @USCPSC to issue a consumer product safety rule to require flame mitigation devices in portable fuel containers. pic.twitter.com/dZubkuRroE
Update: HR 1618 was favorably reported to the full Committee, as amended, by a voice vote.

It would establish a @USCPSC grant program that allows states to purchase and install carbon monoxide alarms in low income or elderly households, facilities that serve children or the elderly, and houses owned by public universities.

Coming up is HR 1618, the Nicholas and Zachary Burt Carbon Monoxide Poisoning Prevention Act of 2019. This bipartisan bill was introduced by @RepAnnieKuster and @RepBuddyCarter. pic.twitter.com/HiameCu01F
Update: HR 3170 was favorably reported to the full Committee, as amended, by a voice vote.
Now up for debate is HR 3170, the Safe Cribs Act of 2019, introduced by Subcommittee Chair @janschakowsky. This act would prohibit dangerous crib bumpers. pic.twitter.com/6v7oL2P77R
Update: HR 3172 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.
Up next: HR 3172, the Safe Sleep Act of 2019, introduced by @RepCardenas, would ban inclined sleepers for infants. pic.twitter.com/s0VoqOFkwk
Update: HR 2211 was favorably reported to the full Committee by a voice vote.

HR 2211, the STURDY Act, was introduced by Subcommittee Chair @janschakowsky. This bill would direct the @USCPSC to issue a consumer product safety standard to prevent dressers from tipping over onto children. pic.twitter.com/gNVhee0YHG
